question.text: What is the amount of heat required (in calories) to convert <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of ice at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mo>℃</mo></math> into steam at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mo> </mo><mo>℃</mo></math>? Given that latent heat of vaporization of water is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>540</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>, latent heat of fusion of ice is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>80</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>, the specific heat capacity of water and ice are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>  and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> respectively.

solution.text:
10 g of ice at -10℃ to ice at 0℃

Q1=cm, ∆θ=0.5×10×10=50 cal

10 g of ice 0℃ to water at 0℃

Q2=mL=10×80=800 cal

10 g of water at 0℃ to water at 100℃

Q3=cm, ∆θ=1×10×100=1000 cal

10 g water at 100℃ to steam at 100℃

Q4=mL=10×540=5400 cal

Total heat required, Q=Q1+Q2+Q3+Q4 

= 50+800+1000+5400 = 7250 cal
